channel.itunes:author: ABC listen
channel.title: Cosmic Vertigo
channel.description: Do you ever feel dizzy when you think about the incomprehensible scale of space? We call that feeling Cosmic Vertigo. Welcome to a head-spinning conversation between two friends about the sparkly -- and not so sparkly -- stuff in the sky.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024, Australian Broadcasting Corporation. All right reserved.

item.title: NAME THAT SPACE SOUND: The Dysons of the sky
item.description:
This is the final episode of Name That Space Sound, our mini-episode in which Karlie plays a mysterious space sound and Corey does his best to guess what it is. This week, the Dysons of the sky... Presenters: Karlie Noon, Corey Tutt

Producer: Ivy ShihExecutive Producer: Joel Werner

Sound engineer: Simon Branthwaite

Podcast tile art by Molly Hunt

item.title: The Box
item.description:
Karlie Noon is the first Indigenous student to obtain a Masters of Astronomy and Advanced Astrophysics, and is currently doing a PhD in Astronomy at the Australian National University. Corey Tutt is the CEO of Deadly Science, a charity that provides science books and early reading material to remote schools in Australia. Our Cosmic hosts have accomplished STEMM careers. But the path to their success was littered with obstacles. Presenters: Karlie Noon, Corey Tutt

Producer: Ivy ShihExecutive Producer: Joel Werner

Sound engineer: Simon Branthwaite

Podcast tile art by Molly Hunt
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation

Our Cosmic hosts have accomplished STEMM careers. But the path to their success was littered with obstacles.
Presenters: Karlie Noon, Corey Tutt
Producer: Ivy Shih
Executive Producer: Joel Werner
Sound engineer: Simon Branthwaite

item.title: Smash The Box!
item.description: What inspires someone to become a scientist? How to fall -- and stay -- in love with STEMM (that’s Science Technology Engineering Maths Medicine) in spite of the many barriers you might meet along the way. With special guest and best friend of the show Professor Lisa Harvey-Smith.Guest:Professor Lisa Harvey-SmithAstrophysicist (UNSW), Author, Australian Government Women in STEM AmbassadorPresenters: Karlie Noon, Corey TuttProducer: Ivy ShihExecutive Producer: Joel WernerSound engineer: Simon BranthwaitePodcast tile art by Molly Hunt

item.title: A microwavable mystery
item.description:
A mystery of astronomical proportions! A lonely night… A strange signal… But who -- or what! -- was the culprit? Presenters: Karlie Noon, Corey Tutt

Producer: Ivy ShihExecutive Producer: Joel Werner

Sound engineer: Simon Branthwaite

Podcast tile art by Molly HuntLaw, Casey, 2016, "The Sound of Fast Radio Burst FRB 121102",https://doi.org/10.7910/DVN/QSWJE6, Harvard Dataverse, V1

item.title: Seven Sisters
item.description:
For the people of many cultures, including Indigenous Australians, the Pleiades constellation tells the story of the Seven Sisters. This ancient story, thought to be up to 100 00 years old, continues to provide insights to modern day astronomy.Presenters: Karlie Noon, Corey Tutt

Producer: Ivy ShihExecutive Producer: Joel Werner

Sound engineer: Simon Branthwaite

Podcast tile art by Molly Hunt

item.title: We do cool things here
item.description:
Australia has a space agency! The Australian Space Agency (ASA) was founded in 2018 -- but what does it do? And how did it come to be? Karlie and Corey are joined by friend of the show Dr Space Junk (aka Associate Professor Alice Gorman) to get the low down on ASA.Guest:Associate Professor Alice GormanCollege of Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences, Flinders University

Presenters: Karlie Noon, Corey Tutt

Producer: Ivy ShihExecutive Producer: Joel Werner

Sound engineer: Simon Branthwaite

Podcast tile art by Molly Hunt

item.title: Space Junk in the Space Trunk
item.description:
There are about 130 million pieces of space junk in orbit around Earth -- and Dr Space Junk knows most of them on a first name basis! Associate Professor Alice Gorman joins Karlie and Corey to chat all things space junk -- from old school satellites that resemble Dr Who props, to red convertibles, and back again.Guest:Associate Professor Alice GormanCollege of Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences, Flinders UniversityPresenters: Karlie Noon, Corey Tutt

Producer: Ivy ShihExecutive Producer: Joel Werner

Sound engineer: Simon Branthwaite

Podcast tile art by Molly Hunt

item.title: Cosmic Dust Bunny
item.description:
Back in 2017 a mysterious, cigar-shaped rock roared into and out of our solar system in a flash! Christened ‘Oumuamua’ it was the first interstellar visitor we’ve seen in our neck of the woods. But this cool observation exposed a not-so-cool side to the astronomy community.Guest:Associate Professor Alice GormanCollege of Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences, Flinders UniversityPresenters: Karlie Noon, Corey Tutt

Producer: Ivy ShihExecutive Producer: Joel Werner

Sound engineer: Simon Branthwaite

Podcast tile art by Molly Hunt

item.title: Not everybody wants a telescope on top of their mountain…
item.description:
To do incredible things -- like take a picture of a black hole -- astronomers rely on telescopes. Telescopes are undeniably cool, and the science people do with them is great -- but they’re not without their problems...Presenters: Karlie Noon, Corey Tutt

Producer: Ivy ShihExecutive Producer: Joel Werner

Sound engineer: Simon Branthwaite

Podcast tile art by Molly HuntVideo footage of Arecibo Observatory collapse from National Science Foundation.

item.title: Black hole, or Curly Wurly?
item.description:
Back in 2019 a network of radio telescopes called the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) took a picture of a black hole for the very first time.Presenters: Karlie Noon, Corey Tutt

Producer: Ivy ShihExecutive Producer: Joel Werner

Sound engineer: Simon Branthwaite

Podcast tile art by Molly Hunt

item.title: New season! New hosts!
item.description:
Everyone’s favourite astronomy podcast is back! And this season, there’s new hosts in the hotseats -- Gomeroi astronomer Karlie Noon, and Deadly Kamilaroi scientist Corey Tutt.Presenters: Karlie Noon, Corey Tutt

Producer: Ivy ShihExecutive Producer: Joel Werner

Sound engineer: Simon Branthwaite

item.title: 019 | Faster than slow
item.description: The International Space Station is travelling in low Earth orbit at a leisurely 7.66km per second (approx). Moving at that speed, the crew of the ISS witnesses a sunrise and sunset every 90 minutes.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: The International Space Station is travelling in low Earth orbit at a leisurely 7.66km per second (approx). Moving at that speed, the crew of the ISS witnesses a sunrise and sunset every 90 minutes.

item.itunes:keywords: science, astronomy

item.title: Cosmic Query | First contact
item.description: The search for alien life continues but at what point do we declare that we are alone in the Universe?
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: The search for alien life continues but at what point do we declare that we are alone in the Universe?
item.itunes:subtitle: The search for alien life continues but at what point do we declare that we are alone in the Universe?
item.itunes:keywords: science, astronomy

item.title: 018 | Quicker than quick
item.description: You'd think we'd notice thousands of explosions in the night sky. Shorter than a millisecond, these bursts were first recorded in 2007 and while scientists know they're there, we are still unsure of their origin.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: You'd think we'd notice thousands of explosions in the night sky. Shorter than a millisecond, these bursts were first recorded in 2007 and while scientists know they're there, we are still unsure of their origin.
item.itunes:subtitle: You'd think we'd notice thousands of explosions in the night sky. Shorter than a millisecond, these bursts were first recorded in 2007 and while scientists know they're there, we are still unsure of their origin.
item.itunes:keywords: science, astronomy

item.title: 017 | Longer than long
item.description: If you wait long enough, would another Universe spontaneously arise in front of you? Chances are it won’t happen in your lifetime… But it could.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: If you wait long enough, would another Universe spontaneously arise in front of you? Chances are it won’t happen in your lifetime… But it could.
item.itunes:subtitle: If you wait long enough, would another Universe spontaneously arise in front of you? Chances are it won’t happen in your lifetime… But it could.
item.itunes:keywords: science, astronomy

item.title: Cosmic Query | clusters and milkshakes
item.description: A serving of Globular Clusters and Amanda's favourite milkshake (it's not chocolate).
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: A serving of Globular Clusters and Amanda's favourite milkshake (it's not chocolate).
item.itunes:subtitle: A serving of Globular Clusters and Amanda's favourite milkshake (it's not chocolate).
item.itunes:keywords: science, astronomy

item.title: 016 | Cooler than Cool
item.description: Temperature levels across the Universe vary wildly. The Boomerang Nebula is the coldest known object, but back on Earth scientists are working towards achieving absolute zero. It doesn't get any cooler than that.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: Temperature levels across the Universe vary wildly. The Boomerang Nebula is the coldest known object, but back on Earth scientists are working towards achieving absolute zero. It doesn't get any cooler than that.
item.itunes:subtitle: Temperature levels across the Universe vary wildly. The Boomerang Nebula is the coldest known object, but back on Earth scientists are working towards achieving absolute zero. It doesn't get any cooler than that.
item.itunes:keywords: science, astronomy

item.title: 015 | Hotter than hot
item.description: The hottest thing in the Universe isn't the core of a planet, or the centre of an exploding star. It's created here on Earth by scientists working at the Large Hadron Collider.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: The hottest thing in the Universe isn't the core of a planet, or the centre of an exploding star. It's created here on Earth by scientists working at the Large Hadron Collider.
item.itunes:subtitle: The hottest thing in the Universe isn't the core of a planet, or the centre of an exploding star. It's created here on Earth by scientists working at the Large Hadron Collider.
item.itunes:keywords: science, astronomy

item.title: Cosmic Query | Lighting up the night
item.description: Could there be a time when we look up at the night sky and see more objects, planets and stars, than dark space? Join Alan and Amanda as they tackle another of your Cosmic Queries.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: Could there be a time when we look up at the night sky and see more objects, planets and stars, than dark space? Join Alan and Amanda as they tackle another of your Cosmic Queries.
item.itunes:subtitle: Could there be a time when we look up at the night sky and see more objects, planets and stars, than dark space? Join Alan and Amanda as they tackle another of your Cosmic Queries.
item.itunes:keywords: science, astronomy

item.title: Cosmic Vertigo | Stargazing Special
item.description:
Stargazing Live on ABC TV gathered astronomers and astrophysicists for three nights of discoveries and record-breaking observation.

Join Alan as he explores the Siding Spring Observatory, where Amanda worked, and asks these professional stargazers (plus one red-haired comedian) what makes them feel Cosmic Vertigo.

Featuring Karlie Noon, Fred Watson, Becky Smethurst, Greg Quicke, Andrea Boyd, Amalia Sicardi, Tim Minchin and Kumi Taguchi.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary:
Stargazing Live on ABC TV gathered astronomers and astrophysicists for three nights of discoveries and record-breaking observation.
Join Alan as he explores the Siding Spring Observatory, where Amanda worked, and asks these professional stargazers (plus one red-haired comedian) what makes them feel Cosmic Vertigo.
Featuring Karlie Noon, Fred Watson, Becky Smethurst, Greg Quicke, Andrea Boyd, Amalia Sicardi, Tim Minchin and Kumi Taguchi.

Featuring Karlie Noon, Fred Watson, Becky Smethurst, Greg Quicke, Andrea Boyd, Amalia Sicardi, Tim Minchin and Kumi Taguchi.
item.itunes:keywords: science, astronomy, stargazinglive

item.title: 014 | Emptier than empty
item.description:
We’re told space is a vast empty vacuum. But how empty can it be, if we know it’s full of stars and black holes, nebulas and galaxies?

Alan and Amanda hop aboard a space elevator and rise through the Earth's atmospheric layers to explore our not-so-empty Universe.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary:
We’re told space is a vast empty vacuum. But how empty can it be, if we know it’s full of stars and black holes, nebulas and galaxies?
Alan and Amanda hop aboard a space elevator and rise through the Earth's atmospheric layers to explore our not-so-empty Universe.

Alan and Amanda hop aboard a space elevator and rise through the Earth's atmospheric layers to explore our not-so-empty Universe.
item.itunes:keywords: science, astronomy

item.title: 013 | Denser than dense
item.description:
Imagine the mass of the sun crushed into something the size of the earth – what you're picturing is a white dwarf. But things can get much more dense than that.

Amanda and Alan deliver a lesson in density with a side of salt and aioli (BYO chips).
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary:

item.title: Cosmic Query | Robots on the moon?
item.description: In Season one, Amanda and Alan took an inventory of what we've left on the Moon: golf balls, a couple of flags, 96 bags of human waste ... But Ashton, a listener, wonders whether any robots (or humans) are up there.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: In Season one, Amanda and Alan took an inventory of what we've left on the Moon: golf balls, a couple of flags, 96 bags of human waste ... But Ashton, a listener, wonders whether any robots (or humans) are up there.

item.title: 012 | Smaller than small
item.description: Zooming right in from the decommissioned dwarf planet Pluto to the humble yet powerful atom helium, Amanda and Alan measure up the smallest things in the Universe — with the aid of a strand of your hair.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: Zooming right in from the decommissioned dwarf planet Pluto to the humble yet powerful atom helium, Amanda and Alan measure up the smallest things in the Universe — with the aid of a strand of your hair.

item.itunes:keywords: science, astronomy

item.title: 011 | Bigger than big
item.description:
The biggest things in the Universe don't necessarily last the longest.

Massive swollen stars, hundreds of times bigger than our own sun, burn through their fuel and either explode into a supernova or become a black hole.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary:

item.title: Cosmic Query | Red planet... Wet planet?
item.description:
Cosmic Vertigo is back — and when they're not discussing the extremes of the Universe, Alan and Amanda are answering the big questions.Your questions.

This week, it's the little issue of water on Mars.

item.title: GUESS WHO'S BACK?!
item.description: Cosmic Vertigo season 2 is COMING SOON! And we need your help. Want to share your own personal experience of Cosmic Vertigo? Or do you have a spacey question you're burning to ask Alan and Amanda? Grab a smartphone, and use the inbuilt audio recorder to record your message. Then email that file to cosmicvertigo@abc.net.au

item.title: 010 | Baby pictures and bird poo
item.description: It’s amazing what you find when you try to see the dawn of time. This season of Cosmic Vertigo ends at the very beginning: the Big Bang.

item.title: 009 | Emptier than empty and getting even emptier
item.description: In the unimaginably vast gaps between galaxies, something is accelerating the universe towards a lonely future. Alan and Amanda shake their heads at Dark Energy.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: In the unimaginably vast gaps between galaxies, something is accelerating the universe towards a lonely future. Alan and Amanda shake their heads at Dark Energy.

item.title: 008 | The invisible wind
item.description: Dark Matter flies through solid walls like a ghost. Humans have buried super-sensitive crystals to try and detect it - and our Universe doesn’t make any sense without it.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: Dark Matter flies through solid walls like a ghost. Humans have buried super-sensitive crystals to try and detect it - and our Universe doesn’t make any sense without it.

item.title: 007 | Black holes don't suck
item.description: Science fiction movies make it pretty clear that black holes are terrifying, all-consuming monsters. For astronomers there’s no cooler place to try and see.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: Science fiction movies make it pretty clear that black holes are terrifying, all-consuming monsters. For astronomers there’s no cooler place to try and see.

item.title: 006 | A pretty exciting place
item.description: It's a patchy, pale river in the sky - and a twirling spiral of 400 billion stars. It’s also headed for a dazzling intergalactic train wreck. Welcome to our Milky Way.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: It's a patchy, pale river in the sky - and a twirling spiral of 400 billion stars. It’s also headed for a dazzling intergalactic train wreck. Welcome to our Milky Way.

item.title: 005 | Where are all the aliens?
item.description: Alan and Amanda debate the number of civilisations that might be out there, get the maths wrong, and argue about whether our biggest barriers to coexistence would be linguistic or… dietary.

item.itunes:summary: Alan and Amanda debate the number of civilisations that might be out there, get the maths wrong, and argue about whether our biggest barriers to coexistence would be linguistic or… dietary.

item.title: 004 | Wobble and wink
item.description: The science of exoplanets is stupendously fast-moving. The more we look for alien worlds, the more of them we find. Thousands and thousands of them, all with terrible names.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: The science of exoplanets is stupendously fast-moving. The more we look for alien worlds, the more of them we find. Thousands and thousands of them, all with terrible names.

item.title: 003 | The bigger they are, the faster they burn
item.description: What makes a star a star? When will Betelgeuse explode? Amanda explores what "any day now" means in astronomy and Alan starts measuring mass in millions of marsupials.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: What makes a star a star? When will Betelgeuse explode? Amanda explores what "any day now" means in astronomy and Alan starts measuring mass in millions of marsupials.

item.title: 002 | Measly little specks of dust
item.description: Our Solar System started out as a chaotic Primordial Pancake. Now it hosts the eight planets we know and love, plus poor old Pluto, plus some other stuff. Like asteroids with their own moons.
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: Our Solar System started out as a chaotic Primordial Pancake. Now it hosts the eight planets we know and love, plus poor old Pluto, plus some other stuff. Like asteroids with their own moons.
item.itunes:subtitle: Our Solar System started out as a chaotic Primordial Pancake. Now it hosts the eight planets we know and love, plus poor old Pluto, plus some other stuff. Like asteroids with their own moons.
item.itunes:keywords: astronomy, podcast, cosmic vertigo, alan duffy, amanda bauer, space, solar system, venus, earth, mars, jupiter, saturn, uranus, pluto, asteroid

item.title: 001 | A giant lump of rock and iron
item.description: It’s drifting away from Earth at the same rate that your fingernails grow, but the Moon is still our closest neighbour - so close, that we’ve left quite a lot of litter on its surface…
item.itunes:author: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
item.itunes:summary: It’s drifting away from Earth at the same rate that your fingernails grow, but the Moon is still our closest neighbour - so close, that we’ve left quite a lot of litter on its surface…

item.itunes:keywords: astronomy, podcast, cosmic vertigo, alan duffy, amanda bauer, moon, space, earth, neil armstrong, buzz aldrin, moon illusion, pink floyd, dark side of the moon
